article.title: Growth Performance and Root Transcriptome Remodeling of Arabidopsis in Response to Mars-Like Levels of Magnesium Sulfate
funding: Prins Bernard Cultuurfonds of the Netherlands
article.abstract: Martian regolith (unconsolidated surface material) is a potential medium for plant growth in bioregenerative life support systems during manned missions on Mars.

sections.introduction: Long duration human missions to Mars must rely on more than just stored supplies and physico-chemical means to regenerate air and clean water.
sections.methods: A homozygous knockout T-DNA insertion line for AtMRS2-10 (At1g80900) was identified by PCR and RT-PCR using the original SALK_100361.41.30.x line.
sections.results: The growth performance of transporter gene knockout mutant lines and their respective wildtype backgrounds grown for four weeks on soil treated with MgSO4·7H2O in solution (0–100 mM) was compared on the basis of shoot fresh weight (FW) biomass and leaf chlorophyll levels.
sections.discussion: The use of regolith on Mars with high levels of hydrated sulfate minerals for bioregenerative life support systems will lead to exposure of plant roots to supra-optimal concentrations of both Mg2+ and SO42− ions in the soil solution.

article.insights_summary: The study shows that knockout mutant lines of the known genes in Arabidopsis encoding root plasma membrane based uptake transporters of Mg2+ and SO42− ions failed to confer an adaptive advantage to a MgSO4·7H2O enriched environment.
